title: CVE-2023-27536: GSS delegation too eager connection re-use

profile.name: curl
profile.about: cURL is an Open Source project providing a library and command-line tool for doing internet transfers

vulnerability_information:
## Summary:
When considering reuse of existing connections different `CURLOPT_GSSAPI_DELEGATION` (libcurl) `--delegation` (curl)  option is not taken into consideration. This can lead to reuse of previously established connection when it should no longer be (as more strict or no delegation was requested).

## Steps To Reproduce:

  1.  `curl --negotiate -u : --delegation "always" https://server/path -: --negotiate -u : --delegation "none" https://server/path`

## Remediation

- Safest option is to not reuse connections if different `CURLOPT_GSSAPI_DELEGATION` levels are being used. It **might** also be correct to not reuse connections with "laxer" `CURLOPT_GSSAPI_DELEGATION`: "none" should only allow reusing "none" level, "policy" should only allow "none" or "policy" level, while "always" can reuse all connections otherwise deemed appropriate for reuse.

## Impact

Existing connection that was established via more lax delegation will be reused for connection that should not succeed due to more restrictive delegation requested. The practical impact can vary, but I believe it is likely quite low, as it should be quite rare to have connections attempted with mixed delegation policies like this.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report!

We will take some time and investigate your reports and get back to you with details and possible follow-up questions as soon as we can!

The likeliness that a user would suddenly no longer have access because you don't allow delegation in the second request seems slim (but not zero). The likeliness that this actually tricks a curl user into thinking it would get logged in as a *different* user in the second request seems similarly far-fetched.

So this is *probably* a valid security problem, but mostly so in theory.

`CURLOPT_GSSAPI_DELEGATION` does not seem to be used for plain negotiate though. Only for krb5 (ftp) and socks5-gssapi. They are the only places that call `Curl_gss_init_sec_context()` which is the only function in libcurl using `data->set.gssapi_delegation`.
The fact that it works for both server auth and proxy auth seems like... a bug.
Pfft, bad grepping of me. It is also used from vauth/krb5_gssapi.c and vauth/spnego_gssapi.c so negotiate is also affected just as @nyymi says.
I've fixed the "efficiency" comment typo in my copy.

additional_data.new_title: CVE-2023-27536: GSS delegation too eager connection re-use

activities.message:
First advisory draft:

CVE-2023-27536: GSS delegation too eager connection re-use
==========================================================

Project curl Security Advisory, March 20th 2023 -
[Permalink](https://curl.se/docs/CVE-2023-27536.html)

VULNERABILITY
-------------

libcurl would reuse a previously created connection even when the GSS
delegation (`CURLOPT_GSSAPI_DELEGATION`) option had been changed that could
have changed the user's permissions in a second transfer.

libcurl keeps previously used connections in a connection pool for subsequent
transfers to reuse if one of them matches the setup. However, this GSS
delegation setting was left out from the configuration match checks, making
them match too easily, affecting krb5/kerberos/negotiate/GSSAPI transfers.

We are not aware of any exploit of this flaw.

INFO
----

CVE-2023-27536 was introduced in [commit
ebf42c4be76df4](https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/ebf42c4be76df4), shipped
in curl 7.22.0.

CWE-305: Authentication Bypass by Primary Weakness

Severity: Low

AFFECTED VERSIONS
-----------------

- Affected versions: curl 7.22.0 to and including 7.88.1
- Not affected versions: curl < 7.22.0 and curl >= 8.0.0

libcurl is used by many applications, but not always advertised as such!

THE SOLUTION
------------

A [fix for CVE-2023-27536](https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/not-yet)

RECOMMENDATIONS
--------------

 A - Upgrade curl to version 8.0.0

 B - Apply the patch to your local version

 C - Do not use the `CURLOPT_GSSAPI_DELEGATION` option

TIMELINE
--------

This issue was reported to the curl project on March 7, 2023. We contacted
distros@openwall on March 13, 2023.

libcurl 8.0.0 was released on March 20 2023, coordinated with the publication
of this advisory.

CREDITS
-------

- Reported-by: Harry Sintonen
- Patched-by: Daniel Stenberg

Thanks a lot!
Published. This issue is now eligible for a bounty claim from [IBB](https://hackerone.com/ibb).

Thanks for your work. The actual monetary reward part for this issue is managed by the [Internet Bug Bounty](https://hackerone.com/ibb) so the curl project itself therefor sets the reward amount to **zero USD**. If you haven't already, please submit your reward request to them and refer back to this issue.
